snippet: The bloodshed that has engulfed Iraq, Lebanon and Syria exposes the emergence of a post-American Middle East in which no broker has the will or power to contain the region’s sectarian hatreds.
abstract: Bloodshed that has engulfed Iraq, Lebanon and Syria over the course of two weeks exposes the emergence of a post-American Middle East in which no broker has the power or will to contain the region's sectarian hatreds; amid this vacuum, fanatical Islamists have flourished in both Iraq and Syria under the banner of Al Qaeda, as the two countries' conflicts amplify each other and foster ever-deeper radicalism.

byline.original: By BEN HUBBARD, ROBERT F. WORTH and MICHAEL R. GORDON
byline.contributor: Ben Hubbard reported from Beirut, Robert F. Worth from Washington, and Michael R. Gordon from Jerusalem. Peter Baker contributed reporting from Washington.

lead_paragraph: The bloodshed that has engulfed Iraq, Lebanon and Syria exposes the emergence of a post-American Middle East in which no broker has the will or power to contain the region’s sectarian hatreds.

headline.main: Power Vacuum in Middle East Lifts Militants
headline.print_headline: Power Vacuum In Middle East Lifts Militants
